2 minutes ago, Red Iron Crown said:

@Alshain Your statement that 1.1 is "unplayable" is demonstrably false, I and many other players seem to be playing just fine. I have even made rovers that work, and planes that can takeoff and land on the landing gear, and landers that use the landing gear? How is that possible when the game is "unplayable"? I'll be the first to admit that 1.1 is not perfect or bug free, but it is far, far from unplayable.

Further, your last post is just naysaying, you don't have a crystal ball and you don't know what 1.2 will be like.

I understand that you are not happy with 1.1 for a variety of reasons and you are entitled to your opinion, but all this hyperbole just makes you sound foolish, IMO. Offer something more constructive than "this update is broken and the next one will be too!" if you want to be taken seriously.

KSP is about building stuff, mostly rockets but also planes, rovers... When I can't design a 30 parts ship without the game crashing, I call it unplayable, at least for me. And I know the weight of this word: I'm the first to correct some people when they call the game unplayable because of some random bug.

Also, about 1.2, I've had the game since 2012 and been following the development since then, and while what @Alshain said might not be 100% true, I personally think there are strong chances that another major bug will break the game for some users. Other bugs may and will be fixed but new ones will arise breaking the game for some people, that is how I percieve the development of this game (and people will say 1.2 was rushed but that's something else).

20 minutes ago, Sirad said:

What would you do if you want to sell the Game to more Customers.

Actually, in my experience, most software companies see a considerable boost to their sales every time they release an update, regardless of how many new features it has or how buggy it is (within reason).  So, in general, I would say the best way (at least as far as the company is concerned) to sell more copies is to release regular and fairly frequent updates and leave the actual number of features and bug fixes as secondary concerns.  As long as there is something new and/or some things fixed, the sales will see a spike...

Note, I am not suggesting that Squad (or any other company) should do this as it may well backfire eventually if they are left as secondary concerns for too long.
